executive_summary:
The Massage Franchises industry includes franchised outlets that provide therapeutic and recreational massage services. The popularity of massage services has surged over the five years to 2021 as consumers increasingly spend on luxury goods. Furthermore, new research touts the health benefits of massages, benefiting the industry. The improving economic environment and increasing visibility of massage franchises are expected to encourage strong growth in the Massage Franchises industry during the period. While the majority of massage therapists are sole proprietors, the popularity of massage franchises has grown over the past decade. Franchisees benefit from efficient operating and support systems, along with increased advertising and name recognition. Therefore, during the current period, revenue is expected to rise an annualized 15.4% to $2.5 billion. Although the industry's growth was disrupted in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, revenue is expected to bounce back with growth of 15.1% in 2021.

As a relative luxury service, the industry's largest market is high-income consumers. During the current period, increasing per capita disposable income encouraged consumers to pursue discretionary services such as massages. Furthermore, preference shifts toward healthier lifestyles strongly benefited this industry. Consumers increasingly recognize the health benefits of massages; according to the American Massage Therapy Association, 50.0% of adults who receive massages do so for health, medical or overall wellness reasons. Moreover, franchises in the industry provide customers with easy access to massage services, and industry brands have been increasing their market penetration over the past five years.

As the industry is young, it is expected to continue growing over the five years to 2026. Increasing health expenditure and consumer spending will likely support the industry's growth. Over the next five years, massage services are expected to become more mainstream and available to a larger customer base. Therefore, IBISWorld projects industry revenue to increase at an annualized rate of 15.8% to $5.2 billion over the five years to 2026. Profit is likewise expected to rise during the period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry has performed strongly over the five years to 2021, aided by favorable economic conditions. During the five-year period, per capita disposable income increased at an annualized rate of 3.3%. Thus, consumers had more discretionary income to spend on luxury goods and services. Additionally, consumer spending increased at an annualized rate of 2.4% over the past five years, indicating a growth in the pool of potential clients.

IBISWorld expects consumers to increasingly seek reputable locations to receive massage services. Massage franchises are expected to attract consumers who have not previously had a massage, while well-positioned brands will likely maintain larger advertising expenditures than sole proprietors. Brand recognition is expected to be a key factor in attracting first-time customers to massage franchises.

IBISWorld expects that wages as a share of revenue for massage services will grow to 55.2% in 2020, up from 49.5% in 2016. Total wages are expected to grow on par with revenue over the five years to 2021, climbing at an annualized rate of 18.0% to reach $1.4 billion. This is likely due to various certified massage therapists in the labor market who demand higher wages than noncertified masseuses.

The Massage Franchises industry has been able to grow rapidly as a result of the popularity of services operators provide. As doctors increasingly recommend massage to treat pain and various ailments, massage franchises are expected to continue attracting consumers. Furthermore, franchisors offer assistance to potential industry players, and there is no specialized knowledge required to open a franchise.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Massage Franchises industry is still relatively young, and since sole proprietors have long controlled the market for massage services, they are expected to continue their dominance. However, the emergence of massage franchises has challenged incumbent massage service providers. Competition is therefore expected to continue at elevated levels as small sole proprietors continue to combat franchise brands.

Improving economic conditions for consumers will help drive demand for industry services as well. Over the five years to 2026, per capita disposable income is expected to rise at an annualized rate of 2.5%. When consumers have more disposable income, they are more likely to spend on discretionary services such as massages. Furthermore, massages have also increasingly been perceived as having health benefits, and this trend is likely to continue.

industry_definition: This industry comprises franchise companies that provide massages to enhance physical function, aid healing and promote relaxation, often in private or group sessions.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: The industry has performed strongly, aided by favorable economic conditions
Brand recognition is expected to attract first-time customers to massage franchises
The industry has grown rapidly as a result of the popularity of services operators provide
The number of franchises is expected to expand as massage services continue to grow in popularity
Improving economic conditions for consumers will help drive demand for industry services
Rising revenue for associated industries will encourage steady demand for the industry's services
The popularity of massage services has surged over the past five years as consumers increasingly spend on luxury goods

market_segmentation.segment_description: The largest consumers of industry goods are individuals in households earning over $100,000. These households demand 31.0% of massage services. Furthermore, consumers in households earning over $75,000 make up 53.7% of the market for the industry in 2021. Industry services are considered a discretionary good. The more disposable income a consumer has, the more likely they are to seek out industry services.

Industry services are not as commonly used by individuals in households in lower income brackets. In 2021, IBISWorld estimates households earning up to, but less than $75,000 make up 46.3% of the industry's market. Moreover, just 10.0% of households earning less than $35,000 demand massage services. These households have a lower amount of disposable income that they can spend on extra personal care.

products_and_services.product_description: A therapeutic massage is designed to relieve pain stemming from the back, joints, muscles and nerves. It concentrates on stimulating muscles deep within the body to promote blood flow and physical healing. In 2021, therapeutic massage services, generally practiced in medical offices and clinics, are expected to account for 45.0% of total industry revenue.

Over the past five years, the number of practitioners of nontherapeutic massage services has grown considerably. Nontherapeutic massage services are generally practiced in massage and spa salons. Examples include energy healing, reflexology and hot stone massages.

Additionally, operators offer prenatal massages to help pregnant women with headaches, backaches and to reduce fatigue. Massage chair services are also offered, yet this segment experiences strong competition from independent massage chair operators in public locations (such as in malls) and from electronic massagers sold through retail chains such as Walmart and Bed, Bath & Beyond. These other massage services are expected to account for 12.0% of total industry revenue in 2021.

tier_1_suppliers: Beauty, Cosmetics & Fragrance Stores in the US
Drug, Cosmetic & Toiletry Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Heating & Air Conditioning Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Vacuum, Fan & Small Household Appliance Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Income levels predominantly determine demand for massage services. Changes in per capita disposable income dictate how much consumers can spend on discretionary services such as massages. A steady increase in per capita income over the past few decades has been one of the main factors driving the outsourcing of personal services such as massages to professionals.

Consumer preferences also impact demand for massage services. Over the past decade, medical research has explicated the potential benefits of massage therapy. As a complementary and alternative medicine often focused on preventative care, demand for massage therapy services has risen over the past few decades as many consumers have taken a proactive wellness approach to health.

According to the Associated Bodywork and Massage Professionals (ABMP) more than 90.0% of massage therapy sessions are paid out of the client's pocket. If future health insurance coverage includes massage therapy, this will increase demand for services as consumers will no longer need to pay the full cost out of pocket.

Consumers' time constraints due to work, family and other commitments also impact demand, especially high-income individuals who are a target market for this industry. As the health benefits of massage services become more apparent among high-income individuals and the population at large, demand for industry services is likely to pick up as these consumers increasingly consider massage services as a valuable way to use spare time.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Given the service-based nature of the industry, imports and exports are not applicable to the Massage Franchises industry. The majority of industry participants service the domestic market.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the greatest share of industry establishments. The region contains 25.7% of the US population, and the distribution of salons closely mirrors this concentration with 23.8% of establishments. Florida has one of the highest concentrations of industry establishments, with 7.8% of the nation's total. Greater migration toward the Southeast region by the elderly.

The Mid-Atlantic accounts for 18.2% of the nation's massage franchisees. The states with the highest concentration of establishments include New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, which hold a respective 9.6%, 3.5% and 3.4% of the total. New York, in particular, has experienced strong growth in the number of massage services establishments. Massage operators locate near these major metropolitan centers because of the large consumer markets in the area.

The West has the next highest share of massage franchisee operators in the nation, with 18.2% of establishments. Establishments in the West are dominated by California, which has the highest percentage of massage franchisee operators in the country, estimated at 11.9% of the total. California is an attractive destination due to its large consumer markets in Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego.

The Great Lakes region houses 13.7% of industry establishments. The major state within the Great Lakes region is Illinois, which contains 4.1% of the industry's establishments. The Great Lakes region, with its large urban centers, constitutes 14.5% of the nation's population. The region's share of establishments fell in the past five years due to lower population growth within the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The District of Columbia and 46 states either regulate the industry or provide voluntary state certification. Moreover, if a state is not regulated, local municipalities may have regulations that industry operators must adhere to, to operate in these areas.
Education requirements for many states include at least 500 hours of hands-on experience performing massage therapy. Practitioners may also be required to pass exams and obtain licenses.
There are both federal and state laws governing franchising, which vary from state to state. Laws generally fall under three categories: disclosure laws, registration laws and relationship laws.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Start-up costs can range from $300,000 to $800,000 depending on the franchise. To get started, a potential franchisee generally searches for his or her preferred business model and contacts a franchise representative.

Once a new entrant becomes a franchisee he or she is provided with ongoing services from the franchisor. This may include newsletters, safety and security procedures, inspections, lease negotiation and co-op advertising.

basis_points.basis_title: Price, service quality, location and customer loyalty
basis_points.basis_description: Competition between industry operators is based on price, service quality, location and customer loyalty. In economic downturns, price-based competition increases as operators adjust to the reduction of consumer's disposable income.

As with many service-based industries, massage franchises are judged by the quality of service provided, making brand recognition essential to a franchise's success. The perception of quality helps operators attract new and loyal customers.
A franchise's location is the third most important basis of competition. By having locations near high-traffic areas, operators increase the likelihood of a customer walking in to receive a massage.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 operators account for 55.1% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four operators accounting for 55.1% of industry revenue in 2021. The industry leader, Massage Envy, generates more than one-fifth of industry revenue alone.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most franchises operate in one state/region
concentration_points.concentration_description: The rest of this industry is highly fragmented, with most franchises only operating in one state or region within the United States, making it difficult for them to obtain greater market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The Massage Franchise industry is highly fragmented, with individual establishments typically operated by a single enterprise. As a result, the cost structures of individual companies are relatively similar, as few firms are able to realize substantial cost savings from scale.

Wages, excluding tips, represent the largest cost for industry operators, and they are estimated to account for 55.2% of industry revenue in 2021. Wages have increased over the five years to 2021 as Industry operators hire licensed massage therapists alongside facility managers, customer service representatives and sales people.

Purchases also represent a significant cost for industry operators because a variety of equipment and tools are needed to operate a massage franchise. For example, some of the items that are purchased include beds, oils, towels, sheets, lotion, stones, incense and candles among other products.
Depreciation is estimated to account for 2.1% of industry revenue in 2021. Massage franchises require equipment like massage beds and tools, which require maintenance and upkeep.

Marketing is expected to account 1.8% of industry revenue in 2021. Larger franchises, such as Massage Envy, spend more on marketing and special discount programs to expand their market share and enter new regions than smaller franchises do.

Rent expenses are relatively high as massage locations count on walk-in clients which requires a store front in a high-traffic, popular location. IBISWorld estimates that in 2021, rent is expected to account for 4.3% of industry revenue.
Utility costs are a significant expense for massage franchise locations. In 2021, 1.1% of industry revenue is expected to be spent on utility expenses.
Other costs for the Massage Franchises industry primarily include insurance and professional service fees. These costs are expected to account for 25.8% of industry revenue in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: As a service-based industry, the Massage Franchises industry is highly labor-intensive and exhibits a low level of capital intensity. Using wages as a proxy for labor and depreciation as a substitution for capital, IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 operators spend on labor in the industry, they will spend $0.04 on capital in 2021.

While some operators use machines and equipment to provide massage services to customers, most establishments rely on the skills of licensed professionals who cannot be replaced by machines. Consequently, massage franchises require minimal capital investment to operate.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the five years to 2021, the Massage Franchises industry is expected to exhibit a high level of revenue volatility as a result of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic.
However, revenue volatility for the industry is typically low to moderate, largely because the key drivers for this industry are not particularly volatile.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Massage Franchises industry has not been disrupted by technological change as the nature of industry services are highly labor intensive and require clients to receive them in person.

While advances have been made in massage therapy techniques and new combinations of massage therapy have been developed to better suit the needs of clients, there has not been any major breakthrough with respect to the use of technology to improve the services provided by this industry.

FAQs.question: What percent of revenue do you spend on advertising?
FAQs.answer: Franchisees pay an annual advertising royalty fee ranging from 2.0% to 6.0%. Pooled advertising funds allow franchises to purchase larger advertising campaigns.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer a referral rewards program to attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: Massage stores benefit mainly from walk-ins and word-of-mouth advertising. Franchises also have the added benefit of some brand recognition. Rewards programs help to turn first-time customers into repeat customers.

FAQs.question: What are your company's pricing strategies, especially in crowded markets?
FAQs.answer: Franchises generally set standard prices. When clients walk into a franchise location, they expect the same experience they received in another location of the same brand.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in high-traffic areas to maximize visibility?
FAQs.answer: Location is very important to massage franchises. Walk-ins constitute a major source of revenue, thus it is beneficial to be located in high-traffic areas.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging new technology, such as mobile phone applications, to streamline booking and communication with customers?
FAQs.answer: Allowing clients to book services on a mobile application will entice a broader consumer base of younger clients as well as decrease human error by automating the booking process.

FAQs.question: What point-of-sale systems (i.e. Square) does your company use to reduce labor costs?
FAQs.answer: Massage services are highly labor-intensive and the industry expends most of its revenue on wage costs. Switching to an automated POS systems will reduce labor costs for operators.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The increasing minimum wage benefits industry employees while increasing costs for operators. Industry operators must register as a franchisee and invest a certain amount of capital as well as pay ongoing fees to a franchisor.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor customer satisfaction? Do you receive a lot of word-of-mouth recommendations? How can you improve customer relations?
FAQs.answer: Successful industry operators strive for positive customer satisfaction to encourage word-of-mouth recommendations.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are to adults aged 20 to 64? How can you market to other age groups? How can you adapt when this age group declines?
FAQs.answer: As individuals aged 20 to 64 represent the largest market for industry services, an increase in the population of this group tends to benefit industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor unemployment rates to plan your business accordingly? How has the current unemployment rate affected your business thus far?
FAQs.answer: Increases in the national unemployment rate tend to decrease downstream demand and industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of increasing consumer spending? How do you take advantage when consumer spending increases?
FAQs.answer: Massage services are discretionary, often even considered luxury goods. Thus, as consumer spending increases, demand for personal luxury services increases.
